Each scenario varies wildly in its objectives, challenging players to approach the game with new ideas and strategies.

Name: The Gauntlet
Description:
This game was developed to be played with the Green Box of Games game system.

The Gauntlet is a deadly race, where you want to be the first to reach the end while avoiding being hammered by your opponents and pelted with arrows. You have to climb over obstacles using the appropriate cards, keep your shield up at the right time, and maybe find a quiet spot to heal your wounds when necessary.

Build a track with the tiles, using brick and lumber symbols as obstacles, and arrows as deadly traps, with the other tiles face down. With one cube to move and three cubes as life points, players will roll a die to determine the available movement points for a round. Cards are drafted from a pool on the table, and then each player chooses three cards as their programmed movement for the round. Brick and lumber cards are necessary to climb obstacles, Arrow cards fire the traps, hammers are for close combat, the shield for protection and the drop for healing.

The winner is the first to reach the end of the track alive!

—description from the designer

Name: Son of Kark
Description:
This game is developed to be played with the Green Box of Games game system.

You are Kark, a successful merchant seeking to expand your trading empire by issuing orders to your sons. Place tiles on the table and add your cubes to them to score points. Three different placements are possible: Market, City or Crossroads, and each score in a different way.

The game is obviously inspired by Carcassonne (Klaus-Jürgen Wrede, 2000), but adapted to fit the components of the Green Box of Games. Basic gameplay is like the original game, you draw a tile, place it, and then choose whether to place one of you pieces on it in order to score points.

Markets (cubes placed in the center of a symbol) score based on the number of tiles with the same symbol on the board.
Cities (cubes in the center of face down tiles) score based on the number of different market symbols around it.
Crossroads (cubes placed on the intersection of four tiles) score at the end of the game, when players sum up who has the most influence over each of the six symbols plus cities.

—description from the designer

Name: BIX
Description: BIX is a two-player card/board game where players play cards to move at least one of their pieces into their opponents golden square. Their are three types of cards; special slot, movement, and effect. Movement cards move pieces directly, while effect cards have effects that range from destroying pieces to drawing cards. Special Slot cards have a surprise effect that can be activated only in certain conditions.

Name: The Tooth Fairy Game
Description:
Petersen Games’ first kids game, under the new imprint Larva Games.

The Tooth Fairy Game is actually FOUR games in one, complete with 125 plastic teeth in 5 colors, five bags in 5 colors, 1 six sided die, 5 tooth fairy cards, and rules in English, Spanish, French, German and Italian!

While all games are good for ages 6 and up, each game is a bit more difficult than the one before it:

That’s My Tooth is the “Baby Teeth” game.
After you’ve had fun playing that game a few times, you can try out Pulling Teeth, the “Adult Teeth” game.
Then there is Lie Through Your Teeth which is a game for those with “Fake Teeth.” That game works best for those who know how to bluff. It is a clever take on the classic “liar’s dice” game.
Finally, there is Treasure Teeth for those rich tooth fairies with “Gold Teeth.” In Treasure Teeth you bid on valuable teeth, trying to get the most money. However, your bid is secretly split up any way you choose between your two hands. But beware, another player will pick WHICH of your two hands will be your real bid! Will you put all your teeth in one hand, hoping they pick that one, divide them evenly, or do you have another ingenious plan in mind?

Name: Olympic Baseball and Softball
Description:
Olympic Baseball and Softball allows you to replay any of the modern Olympic Baseball and Softball tournaments as you play to see who gets the Gold! Each team is rated for Hit ability and Run percentage. You sum up the Hit For (HF) of the attacking team and Hit Against of the defending team, divide the result by two (rounding down) and convert the result to a letter. Roll two six sided die on the Hits Table and cross the result of the roll with the letter you have found before. The number obtained is the number of hits scored by the attacking team during the game. Now check the conversion percentage of the team to see how many hits become runs: roll a percentage die (two ten sided dice of different colors, one of them for the  tens digits, the other for the single digits) for each hit and if the roll is equal or below the percentage factor, it become a run, otherwise not.

Repeat the procedure for the opposing team and you'll have the final result for the game. In case of a tie, use the Killer Instinct rule.

Name: MechAge: Attack of Varanor
Description:
Your Mech's trial mission was a success! You even managed to clear a den of Cat Mutants. The Sprawl should sleep soundly tonight.

Just then, a blast rocks the hanger and reports pour in. A Lizard Mutant, bigger than anything ever seen, has emerged from the water and is destroying the city. Swarms of large parasited attack anyone nearby.

Your work today isn't over yet. Fire up the reactor, reload the magazines, and let's see what this Mech can do...

Adventure scenario expansion for MechAge.


The scenario consists in 1 Scenario card and 2 Mech cards:

     Rules booklet
     Attack of Varanor Scenario card
     Power Sword Mech card
     Heavy Cannon Mech card


Players are expected to provide their own tokens for this scenario:

     1 DEFCON Tracker token
     1 Monster Health token
     1 Parasite Strength token
     1 Population Damage token
     1 Property Damage token
     2 Unique tokens for Varanor and your Mech



Released in the March 2019 Board Game of the Month Club $10+ package, together with MechAge base rules.

Name: ノアロン (Noalon)
Description:
Noalon is a hand management game for two players in which there are only two types of cards.

The game contains an equal number of red and black cards. Each player has a hand of twelve cards and tries to work towards a winning hand. Hands are formed based on the sequence of red and black cards in your hand, so you can't freely rearrange the order of your cards. The other catch is that you draw cards two at a time, insert them next to each other, and always discard two adjacent cards.

Scoring follows this rule: a set is a sequence of N cards starting from one edge of your held cards, followed by the same number N cards of the other color. You may only use one set to calculate your score. If the leftover cards not in the set would form a set on their own then the point value of your hand is half the number of leftovers; otherwise it's the full number of leftover cards.

Points are to be avoided. You can go out if you have four or fewer points in your hand. When someone goes out, players compare hands and the player with more points is the loser, and takes points equal to the difference in points with a bonus for a perfect hand (0 points) or undercut (where the person who went out had the worse hand). The first player to collect nine points loses the game.

-- user summary

Name: The Fort of Gold
Description:
The Fort of Gold (é‡‘ã®ç ¦) is a solitaire game in which you take on the role of a sorcerer manipulating mana to collect seven treasures. There is one deck of treasures and one of magical spirits. Spirits and treasures both have a set of three elemental symbols, where each symbol can be one of earth, air, fire, or water. In order to collect a treasure you need to create a set of one or more spirits that can match with all the elements on the treasure.

However, you may not be able to collect any of the treasures initially exposed. In that case you can swap the exposed treasures or peek at and rearrange the deck, but these both require more demanding combinations of elements.

You win if you can get all seven treasures, but you lose if you're stuck without any legal actions. Can you activate all the spirits before your mana runs out?

Name: グリムフォージ (Grim Forge)
Description:
Grim Forge is a drafting game played over seven rounds.

First you draft the hero cards that will be summon during the game. After that, each round you draw one mana card to place in front of you, and then you go to the Summoning for that round. In this round you use the mana cards you've collected so far to summon a hero.

When summoning a hero, you place them face down in front of you and pointed at another player. All heroes are revealed simultaneously and have one of three effects: they can steal points from the player they point at, they can steal from the neighbors of the player they point at, or they can deflect incoming attacks to the player they point at.

After seven rounds whoever has the most points wins.

—user summary

Name: Anthelion: Conclave of Power – The Folk: Faction Pack
Description:
Hailing from secluded corners of the galaxy, the Folk lived in peace until the galaxy went to war.  Now they protect the sanctity of the Forest Moon with their wits and cunning.

The Folk: Faction Pack introduces the Folk faction into Anthelion.

Components:

     4 Character cards (The Folk)
     1 Location card (Forest Moon)



Released in the March 2019 Board Game of the Month Club $10+ package.
Families: Organizations: Game Designers of North Carolina

Name: Merkez
Description:
Inspired by local elections in Turkey and empty promises, this game casts you as an Urban Planner. Your goal is to impress the current Mayor and score the most points with your blueprint. The blueprint should include plans to build schools with bike roads, animal hospitals, fund funding allocations, provide free Wi-Fi, and assign Civil Servants to hospitals and schools. Every building needs civilians; unemployed civilians (those not assigned to a building) will cost you points. Even if you can't construct a building on your turn, you must build a road or pavement, following the curve dictated by the dice.

The ultimate aim is to position yourself as the next Mayor.

The game unfolds over several rounds, with the following phases in each round:

1- Throw dice.
2- The first player claims a Promise Card (optional).
3- Players claim regions based on the dice roll and draw symbols.
4- End of the round.

You score points by drawing icons in the colored regions. The game ends when there are no free spots left on any player's sheet. The player with the highest score wins!

—description from the designer

Name: Aurora Partsopoly
Description:
A Monopoly variant made and given out by Aurora parts of Lebanon, Indiana. Aurora distributes tractor-trailer parts nationwide, and they created this game as a promotional tool. The game plays as Monopoly, but the properties are all Aurora parts, the railroads become Aurora's distribution centers, etc. Very nicely produced for this kind of item and unique.

—user summary
